content:
I recently hit a strange CSS snag on my Hugo site (Blowfish theme) where my youtubeLite embedded videos would shrink dramatically if I hid the “Related Content” section below them.
The Problem: # With “Related Content” visible: YouTube player size = Normal.
|
With “Related Content” hidden: YouTube player size = Tiny.
|
Why would hiding a separate section break the video size?
The Investigation & Culprit: # Using browser DevTools, I discovered the div container for my article content (div.article-content.max-w-prose) was shrinking to a mere 160px width when there was no text (like related posts) below the video to “prop it open.”
It turned out that a parent div further up, which had a Tailwind-like class such as max-w-fit, was causing this chain reaction of shrinkage when its own content became minimal. My video player, even if set to width: 100%, was only 100% of a tiny parent.
The Fix: CSS to the Rescue # The solution involved two key CSS additions:
Wrapping the Video: I modified my youtubeLite.html shortcode to wrap the element in a new div with the class video-embed-wrapper. <!-- layouts/shortcodes/youtubeLite.html --> <div class="video-embed-wrapper"> <lite-youtube ...></lite-youtube> </div> Targeted CSS: In the custom.css(assets/css/custom.css): /* 1. Style the new video wrapper */ .video-embed-wrapper { width: 100%; max-width: 720px; /* Match lite-youtube's max-width */ margin: 1.5em auto; /* Center and add space */ } .video-embed-wrapper lite-youtube { width: 100%; display: block; } /* 2. Fix the collapsing ancestor container */ /* This targets the problematic div with max-w-fit (or similar) */ section.flex.flex-col > div.min-w-0.min-h-0 { max-width: none; /* Override shrinking behavior */ width: 100%; /* Ensure it takes parent's width */ } How it Works: # The new .video-embed-wrapper gives the video a stable container. More importantly, the CSS targeting the section div forces the article’s main column to maintain a proper width, even without trailing text. This allows article-content (and thus the video wrapper) to size correctly based on the max-w-prose limit.
References: # paulirish/lite-youtube-embed: A faster youtube embed.
summary: I recently hit a strange CSS snag on my Hugo site (Blowfish theme) where my youtubeLite embedded videos would shrink dramatically if I hid the “Related Content” section below them.
title: Wrestling the Shrinking YouTube Embed in Hugo & Blowfish

content:
Any one anomaly might be a random thing, however, if you have enough data, you can tell that it’s not. You can see an anomaly that’s persistent for a sufficiently long time – the probability of it being random is not high.
“you can teach a physicist finance, but you can’t teach a finance person physics”
the speed with which someone solves a problem is not necessarily an indicator of their intelligence or future success
Simons elaborates on some of his principles during the interview:
Be guided by beauty. He compares a well-run company to a beautiful theorem. For example, a company that is very efficient and effective in all aspects can be considered beautiful. Surround yourself with the smartest and best people you can find, and let them do their thing. Trust those you hire. You do not need to micromanage them, especially if they are smarter than you. Don’t run with the pack. He considers himself to be a good but slow thinker. Instead of competing in areas with lots of competition, it’s better to find something original to work on. Don’t give up easily. Give your work a chance to succeed. Hope for good luck. Simons emphasizes that this is the most important principle. However, he also believes that luck favors the prepared mind to some extent. He cites Dennis Sullivan as an example: when Sullivan proves a theorem, he is very prepared and would not attribute his success to luck. Simons distinguishes between this type of “prepared luck” and pure luck. “By taking knowledge seriously, so much more can come from it.” Comment from the interviewer.
References:
The mathematician who cracked Wall Street | Jim Simons - YouTube
A conversation with Jim Simons: Mathematics, Common Sense and Good Luck - YouTube
summary: Any one anomaly might be a random thing, however, if you have enough data, you can tell that it’s not. You can see an anomaly that’s persistent for a sufficiently long time – the probability of it being random is not high.

content:
Hi, my name is Kyo, and welcome to my garden!
This little corner of the internet, “Kyo’s Garden,” is a space where I cultivate and share things that I’m passionate about. Like any garden, it’s a place for growth, a bit of experimentation, and hopefully, some beauty and inspiration.
Here’s what you can find blooming:
Music: Wander through a collection of tunes and artists that resonate with me, soundscapes I’m exploring, or reflections on the music that moves me. Photos: Take a stroll through my visual diary. These are moments I’ve captured, big or small – a glimpse of the world as I see it through my lens. Posts: Here, I plant seeds of thought. You’ll find written reflections, journal entries, and stories on a variety of topics that pique my curiosity and I feel like sharing. Thanks for stopping by! Feel free to look around and enjoy your visit.
summary: Hi, my name is Kyo, and welcome to my garden!
